I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
loan;  and  (ii)  proposed  administration  of  a  loan  to  be  provided  by  Agence  Française  de 
Développement  (AFD),  both  to  the  Socialist  Republic  of  Viet  Nam  for  the  Ha  Noi  Metro  Rail 
System Project (Line 3: Nhon – Ha Noi Station Section).1 
  

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

2. 
Strategic  context  of  urban  transport.  The  Government  of  Viet  Nam  is  well  aware  of 
the impact of inadequate transport infrastructure on economic growth. Failure to invest in major 
public  transport  infrastructure  to  support  a  major  modal  shift  away  from  private  transport  in 
major  cities  will  constrain  economic  growth  and  accelerate  degradation  of  the  urban 
environment.  The  government  supports  transport  sector  investment  to  promote  economic 
growth and protect the environment through a low carbon growth path that reduces greenhouse 
gas  emissions. 2  The  2007–2010  Viet  Nam  country  strategy  and  program  of  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)3 supports  the  government's  investment  program  to  improve  urban 
transport infrastructure and reduce transportation costs. 
 
3. 
Ha Noi is Viet Nam’s capital and the second-largest city in Viet Nam; the population of 
the  greater  urban  area  is  about  6  million,  and  is  expected  to  reach  almost  8  million  by  2025. 
Private vehicles dominate transportation, with about 90% of transport modal share. Inadequate 
road  infrastructure  results  in  heavy  congestion  during  peak  hours,  and  this  will  worsen  when 
motorbike riders switch to cars as their household incomes improve. While the road network is 
expanding  slowly,  the  growth  cannot  meet  the  expected  increase  in  demand,  and  most  inner 
city areas face space limitations on road capacity expansion. Private transport is not sustainable 
as  the  principal  transportation  mode.  A  well-integrated  high  capacity  public  urban  transport 
system  is  essential  to  meet  the  demands  of  Ha  Noi,  and  a  metro  rail  system  is  the  most 
appropriate solution for densely populated inner city areas. Without investment in major public 
transport infrastructure to support a significant modal shift to public transport, economic growth 
will  be  severely  constrained  and  the  urban  environment  will  deteriorate  due  to  high  logistics 
costs and severe congestion. Ha Noi is at an early stage of adoption of private motorization, so 
investment  in  major  public  transport  infrastructure  represents  an  effective  means  to  reduce 
future urban congestion.4 
 
The proposed project5 will develop a new double track metro rail line in Ha Noi,6 which is 
4. 
one of four priority lines of a planned larger urban transportation system under the Ha Noi Urban 
Transport  Master  Plan  (HUTMP).  Metro  line  3  will  (i) facilitate  public  transport connectivity,  (ii) 
greatly  enhance  access  in  five  districts  of  Ha  Noi,  and  (iii)  be  an  important  integral  part  of  an 

                                                
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2   Viet Nam Socio-Economic Development Plan for 2011–2015   
3  ADB. 2006. Country Strategy and Program: Viet Nam, 2007–2010. Manila. 
4   The  same  situation  occurs  in  Ho  Chi  Minh  City,  and  a  metro  system  is  being  concurrently  developed,  for  which 
ADB  has  provided  financing,  approving  a  multi-tranche  financing  facility  of  $540  million  on  14  December  2010.  
ADB. 2010. Multitranche Financing Facility to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for Ho Chi Minh City Urban Mass 
Rapid Transit Line 2 Investment Program. 

5  First posted on ADB website on 16 March 2006. 
6  ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for Preparing the Ha Noi Metro Rail System 

Project. Manila (TA 4900-VIE). 

 2 

improved public transport system, which aims to achieve increased public modal share through 
low-carbon transport that reduces greenhouse gas emissions. 
 
5. 
Ha Noi public transport sector. The existing public transport system consists of a bus 
network that  is  not  well  integrated  between  operators,  is  not  competitive  with  private  transport 
modes, and has a current modal share of around 10%. Traffic planning and traffic management 
systems  are  inadequate  to  effectively  control  city  traffic  demand  and  do  not  promote  public 
transport  usage.  Rapid  growth  in  private  ownership  of  cars  and  motorbikes  has  led  to  heavy 
congestion  along  major  routes  and  inner  city  areas  that  constrains  accessibility,  resulting  in  a 
dangerous  urban  environment  for  commuters.  As  traffic  levels  increase,  high  volume  public 
transport modes are required to both alleviate existing congestion and meet expected long-term 
transportation demand. However, the necessary infrastructure  improvements will be ineffective 
without  complementary  policy  and  regulatory  measures  to  both  promote  public  transport  and 
discourage private transport modes for city residents and suburban commuters. 
 
6. 
The  HUTMP  will  (i)  establish  six  metro  lines  as  a  network  crisscrossing  the  central 
business area and serving outer population centers, with  the initial phases of metro lines 1, 2, 
2A, and 3 expected to be operating by 2020; and (ii) strengthen and expand the bus system and 
make traffic management system improvements, to support a modal shift from private to public 
transport.  The  key  objective  of  the  plan  is  to  increase  public  transport’s  modal  share  to  45%–
50%  of  demand. The  resulting  reduction  in the growth  of  private  vehicle  numbers  will  improve 
the  urban  environment  for  city  residents  by  reducing  accidents,  air  and  noise  pollution;  and 
increasing the number of pedestrian-friendly urban areas. 
 
transport 
7. 
improvements that are proposed up to 2020 are estimated to cost $5.8 billion, consisting of $5.2 
billion for four priority metro lines and $0.6 billion for other public transport improvements. The 
central government is providing financing for the infrastructure components, and the Ha Noi city 
government  financing  the  operational  equipment  and  systems.  Annual  budgetary  allocations 
can  meet  less  than  15%  of  the  HUTMP  financing  requirements,  so  this  shortfall  will  require 
financing from other sources, such as  international financial institutions and the private sector. 
Recurrent expenditures for public transport services are funded primarily from allocations under 
the  Ha  Noi  city  budget,  but  sources  of  revenue  are  not  optimized.  Bus  fares  are  kept  low  to 
compete  with  private  transport, 7  resulting  in  subsidies  for  the  existing  bus  services.  Cost 
recovery  is  further  reduced  by  the  inefficient  institutional  arrangements  for  establishing, 
allocating,  and  operating  bus  routes.  Improving  public  transport  sustainability  requires  the 
establishment of high capacity  metro lines to offer an efficient, affordable alternative to private 
transport, and restriction of private vehicles through economic and other measures. 
 
8. 
The  project  will  complement  ongoing  developments  in  interconnected  urban  transport 
systems and public transport management reform, including proposed bus rapid transit lines, to 
meet  user  demand  for  better  services.  Other  developments—including  proposed  new  feeder 
bus links to the metro system, enhanced integration and accessibility at stations, "park and ride" 
facilities, pedestrian-friendly access, and the institution of policy changes—will be implemented 
concurrently  through  a  proposed  loan  using  the  Clean  Technology  Fund  (CTF) 8  and  ADB 
financing in 2012. 
                                                
7  Private  transport  costs  are  kept  artificially  low  due  to  pricing  of  private  vehicles,  parking,  and  vehicle  operating 

Public  transport  financing  and  sustainability.  The  HUTMP  public 

8  The CTF is part of the multidonor global Climate Investment Fund, which supports low-carbon transport to promote 
greenhouse gas emission reduction. Under the CTF, 2009  Clean Technology Fund Investment Plan for Vietnam, 
Washington, DC, approved 1 December, $50 million has been allocated from the CTF to support sustainable urban 

costs. 

 

  
Lessons.  For  large transport  infrastructure  projects  in Viet  Nam,  experience indicates9 
9. 
strong support is required to avoid implementation delays, ensure quality of works are achieved 
and  build  sustainable  institutions.  Poor  local  capacity  affects  timely  implementation  of  land 
acquisition  and  resettlement,  so  adequate  time  and  strengthening  are  important.  These  have 
been  incorporated  into  the  project  design  and  through  proposed  technical  assistance  from 
cofinancing partners and proposed ADB financing in 2012. 
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

10. 
The  impact  of  the  project  will  be  the  establishment  of  an  integrated  sustainable  public 
transport system in five districts of Ha Noi. The outcome will be competitive metro rail services 
along the project corridor. 
 
C. 

Outputs 

(e.g., 

track  work, 

rolling  stock, 

The  project  outputs  will  be:  (i)  metro  line  3  is  operational;  and  (ii)  improved 

11. 
implementation capacity of Ha Noi Metropolitan Rail Transport Project Board (HRB).  
 
The  construction  of  metro  line  3  will  include:  (i)  all  civil  works  for  metro  line  310,  with  a 
12. 
total  length  of  12.5  km  (3.6  km  is  underground,  8.4  km  is  elevated,  and 500  m  in  a  transition 
ramp) of a dual track rail metro line for phase 1 from Nhon to Ha Noi main railway station,11 and 
including  the  depot  with  ancillary  buildings  at  Nhon,  elevated  viaducts,  transition  tunnel  portal, 
bored tunnels, and 12 stations; and (ii) electrical and mechanical (E&M) systems, including all 
traction  power,  signaling  and 
railway  systems 
telecommunications,  E&M  systems  and  facilities,  ticketing  system  and  ancillary  services,  and 
facilities required to operate a modern metro line). 
 
Improved  implementation  capacity  to  HRB  will  be  provided  to  complete  the  detailed 
13. 
design,  procurement  assistance,  and  construction  supervision  for  all  civil  works  and  E&M 
systems, to be funded by Direction Générale du Trésor (DGT). Additional assistance to HRB will 
be  provided  for  verification  of  engineering  designs  and  estimates,  project  management,  and 
design  safety  audit,  to  be  funded  by  AFD.  Further  project  management  support,  capacity 
development, and studies for integrating the project with other public transport will be financed 
and implemented under a separate ADB loan (para. 18). 
 
D. 
 
14. 
The project is estimated to cost $1.08 billion, including taxes and duties of $73.6 million. 
The  total  cost  includes  physical  and  price  contingencies,  interest,  and  other  charges  during 
implementation. The ADB loan will provide $293 million. 
 
15. 
The  financing  plan  includes  ADB  financing  of  $293  million  for  civil  works  and  E&M 
systems,  and  AFD  joint12 cofinancing  for  €23.1  million  ($30.0  million  equivalent)  and  parallel 
cofinancing  for  €86.9  million  ($113.0  million  equivalent)  for  civil  works,  E&M  systems,  and 

Investment and Financing Plans 

                                                                                                                                                       
transport  measures  for  Ha  Noi  metro,  which  will  be  processed  by  ADB  for  approval  in  2012  and  linked  to  the 
project through loan conditions.

million  ($95  million  equivalent)  for  civil  works  and  E&M  systems  and  DGT  parallel  cofinancing

16. 
The  government  has  requested  $293  million  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources  to 
help finance the project. The loan will have a 25-year term, including a grace period of 5 years, 
an  annual  interest  rate  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate 
(LIBOR)-based lending facility, a commitment charge of 0.15% per year, the interest and other 
charges during construction to be capitalized in the loan, and such other terms and conditions 
set  forth  in  the  draft  loan  and  project  agreements.  The  government  has  provided  ADB  with  (i) 
the reasons for its decision to borrow under ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility based on these 
terms  and  conditions,  and  (ii)  an  undertaking  that  these  choices  were  its  own  independent 
decision and not made in reliance on any communication or advice from ADB.

 E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

17. 
The  executing  agency,  Ha  Noi  People’s  Committee  (HPC),  has  established  an 
interdepartmental steering committee for the full metro system development in Ha Noi, chaired 
by the vice chairman of HPC,13 which is responsible for project oversight and coordination. The 
HRB  was  established  in  2001  with  the  responsibility  of  overseeing  the  planning,  design,  and 
implementation of metro line 2 and metro line 3 in Ha Noi. A Project Implementation Division 1 
has been established within HRB under one of its vice directors, which is responsible for day-to-
day management and coordination of implementation of metro line 3, including compliance with 
ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time), Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time), and Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). 
 
Capacity development in the form of consulting services and training will be provided to 
18. 
strengthen the capability of the HRB and HPC public transport agencies. The proposed capacity 
development  will  be  separately  financed  and  implemented  by  ADB, 14  and  will  provide  (i) 
additional  project  implementation  support,  (ii)  capacity  building  and  training  of  HRB,  and  (iii) 
sustainable transport studies to improve metro integration with the public transport system and 
determine policy measures to support increased public transport usage. 
 
19. 
the project administration manual (PAM).15

5 

 

 A. 

Technical 

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

20. 
The  Ha  Noi  Urban  Transport  Master  Plan  identified  metro  line  3  as  a  priority  line,  and 
implementation  is  being  coordinated  closely  with  three  other  metro  lines  being  concurrently 
developed,  with  quarterly  financier  coordination  meetings  held  to  ensure  common  issues  are 
well  integrated.  The  project  feasibility  study  was  completed  by  DGT-funded  consultants  and 
approved in April 2009 and the detailed design is expected to be completed by June 2011. The 
project  is  technically  viable,  with  system  technology  choices  based  on  efficient  and  proven 
designs,  station  layouts  designed  for  future  integration,  depot  facilities  developed  to  maximize 
land usage and accommodate future extensions, and common technical standards adopted for 
interlinked facilities between different metro lines. 
 
21. 
Fully  integrated  facilities  will  allow  seamless  transfers  at  metro  line  3  stations  to  other 
metro  lines  or  public  transportation  modes,  and  to  private  transport.  Suitable  integrated 
sustainable  urban  transport  measures  will  be  implemented  under  the  proposed  loan  in  2012, 
which  will  address  (i)  integrated  accessibility  at  stations;  (ii)  coordination  with  overall  public 
transport,  including  bus  routes;  and  (iii)  necessary  policy  measures  to  support  modal  change. 
To  enhance  metro  system  integration,  the  HPC  is  expected  to  establish  by  2012  a  public 
transport authority with responsibility for planning, developing and regulating all public transport 
in  Ha  Noi.  Operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  of  the  metro  system  will  be  under  a  separate 
agency,  with  HPC  creating  a  steering  committee  in October  2010  to  establish  the metro O&M 
entity by the end of 2012. Options for private sector metro operation will be considered once the 
ridership  has  become  stable  to  ensure  investor  risk  is  reduced  and  owner  guarantees  are  not 
required. 
 
B. 

Economic and Financial 

22. 
The  project  will  directly  benefit  public  transport  users  and  communities  in  five  districts 
and indirectly benefit all transport users in Ha Noi. The main benefits are derived from improved 
access to better, safer, cheaper, more reliable, and faster transportation, with additional benefits 
from  road  accident  cost  reduction,  deferred  capital  costs  of  public  transport  and  reduced  road 
maintenance  costs.  Greenhouse  gas  emissions  and  traffic  congestion  will  be  alleviated, 
providing  social  benefits  that  include  improvements  to  air  quality,  access  to  government 
services, and community quality of life. 
 
23. 
Transport demand forecasts were prepared for the economic analysis. These cover the 
greater  Ha  Noi  region,  with  a  combined  population  of  6.4  million  in  2007.  Daily  demand  for 
metro  line  3  is  forecast  to  be  157,000  loadings  at  opening  in  2016,  increasing  to  458,000 
loadings  in  2030.The  project  has  an  estimated  economic  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  of  12.7%  and 
economic  net  present  value  discounted  at  12%  is  $67.1  million.  While  the  EIRR  is  low,  it  is 
typical of high-investment long-return projects; significant secondary benefits not included in the 
analysis  are  logistics  improvements,  increases  in  property  values  and  tax  revenues,  and  the 
high  non-transport  congestion  costs  that  would  occur  without  the  project.  The  sensitivity  and 
switching  value  analyses  show  that  the  EIRR  is  marginal,  even  with  changes  in  user  benefits 
and  in  project  costs  of  5%,  so  there  is  moderate  risk  that  the  entire  project  will  not  reach  the 
EIRR  threshold  of  12%.  While  civil  works  costs  are  at  high  risk  of  increasing  above  5%, 
particularly for the underground section where actual ground conditions could vary, there is also 

6 

 

 

 the  potential  for  benefits:  the  development  of  the  Ha  Noi  road  network  is  unlikely  to  occur  as 
planned, and the resultant constrained capacity would increase private vehicle operating costs. 
 
For  the  financial  analysis,  operating  cost,  but  not  capital  cost, 16 is  covered  by  fare 
24. 
revenue.  The  base  case  assumes  that,  by  the  start  of  operation,  reorganized  bus  routes  and 
other  integration  measures  to  optimize  public  transport  will  have  been  implemented.  At  the 
assumed fare of D3,300 per boarding, the forecast of strong patronage and annual fare revenue 
in  the  starting  year  (2016)  yields  a  fare  box  ratio17 that  equals  or  exceeds  1.  The  project  is 
anticipated  to  require  a  total  subsidy  over  the  project  life  of  $935  million  and  local  subsidy  of 
$597  million.  The  financial  rate  of  return  after  tax  is  1.8%,  which  exceeds  the  calculated 
weighted average cost of capital of 1.3%. If the urban public transport system optimization does 
not  materialize,  the  starting  year  daily  fare  revenue  drops  by  40%,  and  the  local  subsidy 
required is $830 million, up 35% from the base case, which constitutes a substantial increase in 
the subsidy burden on the central government. 
 
C. 

Governance 

25. 
National  and  local  governance  performance  in  Viet  Nam  has  improved  recently.  Public 
finance  management  reform  has  brought  increased  disclosure  of  public  accounts,  higher 
accounting  standards,  and  progress  on  budgetary  rules.  The  November  2005  Law  on 
Procurement  and  regulations  in  2006  and  2008  have  established  national  bidding  documents. 
Dialogue  continues  with the  government  with  a  view  to  harmonizing  national  and  international 
procedures.  Measures  to  address  corruption  have  improved,  with  revisions  to  the  Anti-
Corruption  Law  in  August  2007  that  established  a  national  anticorruption  steering  committee. 
The  government  is  committed  to  reforming  national  institutions  to  reduce  malfeasance  waste 
and  improve  development  effectiveness.  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to 
date)  was  explained  to  and  discussed  with  the  Ministry  of  Finance  and  HRB.  Specific  policy 
requirements and supplementary measures are described in the PAM. 
 
The  project  will  use  international  competitive  bidding  to  improve  oversight  and  mitigate 
26. 
corruption,  which 
implementation  delays  are  avoided  through 
information  sharing.  The  bidding  process  will  be  further  enhanced  by  improved  transparency, 
information disclosure, oversight and monitoring, mitigation of fraud and collusion risks, handling 
of complaints, and sanctions and remedies. 
 
D. 

Poverty, Social, and Gender 

improves  governance 

if 

27. 
The  project  is  a  general  intervention  with  indirect  poverty  reduction  impacts.  Major 
beneficiaries will be public and private transport users, with women, students in universities and 
colleges along the metro, children, and older people expected to benefit the most from improved 
transportation,  as  well  as  communities  in  districts  along  the  project  corridor.  Local  economies 
are  expected  to  improve  as  a  result  of  business  opportunities  created  through  improved  and 
cheaper  transport,  and  residents  will  further  benefit  through  improved  quality  of  life  resulting 
from reduced congestion and pollution. Other beneficiaries include workers and traders traveling 
between the western part of Ha Noi and the central business district and service or commercial 
establishments near the metro stations. Project districts will benefit from temporary construction 
jobs  and  local  employment  in  O&M.  Women  will  be  encouraged  to  work  and  will  be  treated 
                                                
16 Under Railway Law 2005, the Ha Noi People’s Committee will be responsible for financing rolling stock and E&M 
systems,  land  and  resettlement,  and  incremental  administration,  so  the  central  government  will  relend  any 
borrowing for these items. All other project works will be provided as grants. 

17 Fare revenue divided by O&M cost. 

7 

 

 8 

 

equitably. HRB will ensure that employment opportunities are announced to local communities 
and will also ensure that contractors conform to appropriate labor laws and standards, including 
targets for women’s employment. HRB will monitor the use of local labor and appropriate labor 
laws  and  standards  within  the  first  3  months  of  the  commencement  of  each  construction 
contract and take appropriate action to improve the employment and compliance if needed. 
 
28. 
The potential adverse social impacts from the project are (i) increased risks of exposure 
to  HIV/AIDS  and  human  trafficking  of  women  and  children  during  construction  and  operation 
due to the influx of construction workers, and (ii) increased commuter traffic. Safety risks for the 
communities  along  the  road  are  expected  to  increase  due  to  the  higher  concentration  of 
pedestrians  near  stations.  These  risks  will  be  addressed  through  the  HIV/AIDS  and  human 
trafficking  awareness  and  prevention  program  and  the  public  transport  safety  program,  to  be 
funded separately. All civil works contracts under the project incorporate provisions and budgets 
requiring  that  contractors  carry  out  these  programs,  in  coordination  with  the  government's 
programs and other initiatives under the proposed capacity building loan. 
 
The project has been classified as effective gender mainstreaming; a gender action plan 
29. 
has  been  developed  that  effectively  mitigates  negative  impacts  and  includes  positive  design 
features. The gender action plan will include but not be limited to: (i) use of employment targets 
for  women  and  gender-specific  core  labor  standards  for  contracts  and  other  employment 
generation, (ii) consideration of gender-inclusive physical design features18 in infrastructure, and 
(iii) mitigation of the gender-related resettlement impacts. 
 
E. 

Safeguards 

30. 
Environment.  The  project  has  been  classified  as  environment  category  A  and  an 
environmental impact assessment (EIA) has been prepared to meet the requirements of ADB’s 
Safeguard  Policy  Statement.  An  environmental  management  plan  (EMP)  covering  the  depot, 
viaduct and tunnel sections of the project has been prepared. The recommended environmental 
mitigation  measures  and  monitoring  activities  cover  the  preconstruction,  construction,  and 
operation  stages  of  the  project.  Major  issues  addressed  in  the  EMP  pertain  to  spoils  disposal 
and  impacts  on  air  quality  and  noise,  traffic,  culturally  significant  sites  and  undiscovered 
archaeological relics, groundwater quality, and the health and safety of workers and the public. 
The  EMP  also  specifies  that  the  contractors  shall  develop  and  implement  environmental 
management action plans in the form of specific management plans on dust and noise control, 
traffic management, spoils disposal, spill management, occupational and community health and 
safety,  and  emergency  response.  The  EMP  clearly  defines  the  institutional  arrangements  and 
responsibilities for its implementation and includes an environmental  training program for HRB 
and  its  project  implementation  unit  to  develop  their  environmental  management  capacity. 
Several public consultations involving affected households and local officials in the project area 
were  conducted  during  the  preparation  of  the  EIA.  The  results  of  these  consultations  are 
documented in the EIA, while environmental concerns raised are addressed in the EMP. 
 
31. 
A grievance redress mechanism based on existing legal provisions has been developed 
to  facilitate  resolution  of  complaints  regarding  the  project’s  environmental,  resettlement,  and 
other 
that  the  required  mitigation  and  monitoring  measures  are 
implemented, HRB shall include the EMP in the bidding documents for civil works. The results 
of semiannual EMP implementation monitoring shall be submitted by HRB to ADB. An external

 environmental  monitoring  expert  will  verify  the  monitoring  information  submitted  to  ADB  and 
assess if the EMP is being implemented as required. 
 

32. 
Resettlement.  Resettlement  impacts  are  significant  and  the  project  is  classified  under 
category A. In the phase 1 Nhon depot area, there were 234 households (approximately 1,170 
persons)  affected  by  the  acquisition  of  14  hectares  of  productive  land.  Resettlement  planning 
and  compensation  for  Nhon  Depot  phase  1  started  in  2006,  while  compensation  and  site 
clearing took place from March 2007 to January 2008. Resettlement due diligence was carried 
out and a corrective action plan has been prepared. A resettlement plan for Nhon Depot phase 
2,  the  access  line,  and  the  main  line  has  been  prepared  and  includes  provisions  ensuring 
women’s  needs  are given  equal  consideration  as  those  of men.  For  the Nhon Depot  phase  2, 
the access line, and the main line, it is estimated that there are about 150 displaced persons; 90% 
are households and 10% private companies and government institutions. 

Indigenous  people.  The  project  is  classified  under  category  C;  no  further  action  is 

33. 
required.

interfaces  and  difficult  construction

patronage. The risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4.

9 

 

 Procurement  and  safeguards  due  diligence  constitute  the  greatest  risk  during  project 
35. 
implementation.  Safeguard  issues  pose  some  risk  as  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  is 
required  for  all  underground  stations  and  some elevated  facilities.  The  HPC  is  responsible for 
ensuring  that  bus  transport  is  significantly  developed  prior  to  the  operation  of  the  metro  lines 
and for policy changes to encourage the use of public over private transport. It is expected that 
benefits and positive impacts will outweigh any mitigation costs. 
 

IV. 

ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 

36. 
The government and the HPC have assured ADB that implementation of the project will 
conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in  the  PAM  and  loan  documents.  The  government  and  the  HPC  have  agreed  with  ADB  on 
certain  covenants  for  the  project,  which  are  set  forth  in  the  loan  agreement  and  project 
agreement. 

 

The  European  Investment  Bank,  AFD,  and  DGT  have  agreed  to  comply  with  ADB’s 
37. 
Safeguard Policy Statement requirements for all components to be financed under the project. 
For  the  one  jointly  cofinanced  contract  with  AFD,  ADB  procurement  and  disbursement 
guidelines will apply. 
 

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 

38. 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve 
 

(i) 

(ii) 

the  loan  of  $293,000,000  to  the  Socialist  Republic  of  Viet  Nam  for  the  Ha  Noi 
Metro Rail System Project (Line 3: Nhon – Ha Noi Station Section), from ADB's 
ordinary  capital  resources,  with  interest  to  be  determined  in  accordance  with 
ADB's London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility, for a term of 
25  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  5  years;  and  such  other  terms  and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan 
and project agreements presented to the Board; and 
the administration by ADB of a loan not exceeding the equivalent of $30,000,000 
to  the  Socialist  Republic  of  Viet  Nam  for  the  Ha  Noi  Metro  Rail  System  Project 
(Line 3: Nhon – Ha Noi Station Section), to be provided by Agence Française de
